title: Parliament Opt To Debate Revamping Current FA System In Place
text:
Parliament Opt To Debate Revamping Current FA System In Place Sat Feb 04 2017 10:33:23   10:33:23 GMT+0000 (GMT) Josh Lawless Josh Lawless in football 
The current system and way of working that the FA adopt at present could be set for a revamp if Parliament have their way. 
Several members of the government feel as though the current FA set-up is dated and despite making their opinions clear, have had no response. 
There has now been movement on that front however, as Culture, Media and Sport Committee have been in successful in arranging a debate, to be held in the House of Commons on Thursday 9th February, with the possibility of news laws being put in place. 
Damian Collins, an MP, and the chief on the committee and outlined his intentions to try and bring the FA "more into line"with the way modern companies and bodies are run. 
He said: 
"We do not believe the FA will comply voluntarily: it can survive easily without the government's contribution of money to grassroots sport, and there are powerful vested interests that refuse to accept the right of all those involved in football to play a role in the governance of the sport. 
"We are therefore preparing a draft bill to bring the structure of the FA, especially its board and council, more into line with modern company practice and the government's guidelines for sports bodies." 
The Committee's ideas for a reform include wanting fans, women, BAME groups and others at grassroots to have far more involvement in the sport and make it more culturally diverse. 
Several former FA representatives have made their thoughts be known about the body we see today, stressing the fact that the financial sway of the Premier League has a "knock-on" effect to the rest of the football system in England, while also believing that some members of the board are not qualified for the job at hand. 
It's certainly keeping an eye out for the results of the debate next week.
